RMP*eSubmit

EPA asked that all facilities use this method to submit RMPs to improve data quality and to enable regulated facilities to readily access their RMPs. Emergency Response Procedures

City staff utilizes its Emergency Action Plans to provide step-by-step procedures for emergency response in the unlikely event of an accidental release. Revised versions of the City’s Emergency Action Plans are provided in Section 13. The key elements of the Emergency Action Plans are as follows:

•	All plant staff (including administrative and clerical staff) is trained in the specific elements of the emergency response program.
•	The chlorine storage facility is equipped with electronic gas detectors and chlorine scrubbers. The gas detectors have an audible alarm and alert the City’s central operations control room.
•	In the event of an IDLH release, or one deemed unmanageable by on-site personnel, an alarm at the facility will automatically inform the City of San Buenaventura Fire Department of the release; in addition, on-site personnel at the facility would immediately contact the Fire Department. With assistance from City staff, the Fire Department would conduct emergency response activities. City staff is trained in first aid procedures.

Hypothetical Accidental Release Scenarios

The Risk Management Plan must assess the downwind impacts of hypothetical accidental releases. EPA requires facilities to model the distance that a plume of released gas would travel before it dispersed to an ambient concentration equal to the “Toxic Endpoint Concentration.” The Toxic Endpoint Concentrations for various compounds were specified by EPA, and are generally concentrations that would cause no physical harm but could interfere with people’s ability to leave the area. The Toxic Endpoint Concentrations for the RMP chemicals at the facility are 0.0087 parts per million (ppm) of chlorine in air and 0.14 ppm of aqueous ammonia in air. Accidental Releases during Past 5 Years

The AWTP has not had any releases during the past five years that resulted in any injuries, off-site evacuations, or property and environmental damage.

Accidental Release Prevention Program

In compliance with Federal RMP, CalARP and PSM requirements, the City has developed an accidental release prevention program to minimize the potential for an on-site or off-site accidental release. These procedures are summarized in Sections 1 to 15. The accidental release prevention program includes the following elements:

•	Review of the design of all equipment and controls for the chlorine and aqueous ammonia systems to ensure they are properly designed and installed.
•	Updating of standard operating procedures to include specific information on safety procedures. All procedures must be reviewed and certified annually.
•	Initial safety training and three-year refresher training for all operators and maintenance staff.
•	Procedures to ensure that all contractors receive safety training on hazardous chemical release response.
•	Regular inspection of all equipment, monitoring systems and controls, with stringent documentation of all inspections.
•	Prompt corrective action for any non-conforming items identified by the regular inspections.
•	Rigorous safety reviews conducted prior to system startup, if any equipment or operations are modified.
•	Rigorous investigation of any incidents that have the potential to cause or caused chlorine releases.

Introduction

This Risk Management Program (RMP) plan for the City of San Buenaventura’s (City) Avenue Water Treatment Plant (AWTP) has been prepared in accordance with the USEPA Chemical Accident Prevention Rule (Clean Air Act, Section 112-r-7, Risk Management Program), the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program and the CalOSHA Process Safety Management Standard for the chlorine disinfection system located at the facility. The amount of 19% aqueous ammonia at this facility is above CalARP threshold quantities. 
This current 5-year RMP update is required by the Federal RMP, CalARP, and CalOSHA PSM programs due to the quantities of gaseous chlorine and 19% aqueous ammonia used and stored at the Avenue WTP. The last RMP update was prepared and submitted to EPA in 2018.

Federal RMP, CalARP and PSM Applicability

In California, the state-equivalent of the Federal RMP is the CalARP program, which replaced the California Risk Management and Prevention Program (RMPP). The CalARP program requires facilities that handle regulated substances on the Federal extremely hazardous substances list (or the State list of regulated substances), in quantities greater than Federal or State threshold quantities, to submit a RMP plan. The Federal RMP, CalARP and PSM threshold quantities for chlorine are 2,500, 1,500 and 100 pounds respectively. Chlorine is subject to CalARP requirements until it is injected into water (reducing the concentration to below 1 percent). Although not regulated by Federal RMP and CalOSHA PSM regulations, 19% wt. aqueous ammonia is regulated under the CalARP program. The threshold quantity for aqueous ammonia as a gas or in solution is 500 pounds.

The City can store a maximum of 30,000 pounds of gaseous chlorine at the AWTP. In addition, the City stores a maximum of approximately 26,316 pounds of 19% wt. aqueous ammonia at the AWTP.
